Title: Cody Bellinger Has Surgery On Shoulder
Content: Los Angeles Dodgers outfielder Cody  Bellinger (shoulder) underwent surgery on Tuesday to fix the right shoulder that he dislocated while celebrating a home run in Game 7 of the National League Championship Series against the Braves. Bellinger will start his rehab in Arizona next week and should be ready for spring training in 2021. The 25-year-old said that doctors popped his shoulder back into place "real quick" and he returned to center field to finish the game. He didn't miss any games on the way to beating the Rays in the World Series. Bellinger hit 12 home runs this year and finished with a .239 average and 30 RBI. The power-hitting left-hander was a bit of a disappointment during the regular season, but he remains a high-end fantasy outfielder going into the 2021 season.

Title: Mike Clevinger Will Undergo Tommy John Surgery
Content: The San Diego Padres and starter Mike Clevinger (elbow) agreed to a two-year contract extension through 2022 on Monday. The team also announced the right-hander will undergo Tommy John surgery and miss the 2021 season. Clevinger registered a 2.84 ERA after joining the Friars midseason, but an elbow impingement limited him to just one inning in the playoffs. A rough setback for both the 29-year-old and the Padres lofty expectations, Clevinger should be ready by 2022. Through five big-league seasons, Clevinger possesses a 3.19 ERA, 1.19 WHIP and 10.0 K/9 but has battled a myriad of injuries. Still a hold in dynasty formats, Clevinger will likely be a risk-reward redraft SP2 once he's deemed healthy.

Title: Braves Sign Drew Smyly To One-Year Deal
Content: The Atlanta Braves signed left-hander Drew Smyly to a one-year, $11 million deal on Monday. The 31-year-old went 0-1 with a 3.42 ERA in five starts and two relief outings for the Giants last season after San Francisco signed him to a one-year deal in January. He was released by the Rangers after going 4-7 with a 6.24 ERA in 21 starts and four relief appearances in 2019. Smyly underwent Tommy John surgery in 2017 and spent most of the 2018 season recovering. The southpaw will provide rotation depth behind youngsters Max Fried, Ian Anderson and Mike Soroka, who missed most of 2020 with a torn Achilles. If he makes any starts for the Braves, Smyly will strictly be a DFS streamer based on the matchup.

Title: Blake Snell, Kevin Kiermaier Available In A Trade?
Content: The Tampa Bay Rays could be receptive to trading players like starting pitcher Blake  Snell and outfielder Kevin  Kiermaier this offseason as they look to balance their budget after losing significant revenue in the COVID-19 shortened 2020 season. Tampa has already declined the 2021 options on starter Charlie Morton ($15 million) and catcher Mike Zunino ($4.5 million). Kiermaier will make $11.5 million in 2021 and $12 million in 2022, and Snell will receive $10.5 million next year, $12.5 million in 2022 and $16 million in 2023. Outfielder Hunter  Renfroe, who is projected to make between $3.6 million and $4.3 million in arbitration, could be a non-tender candidate for the Rays.

Title: Freddie Freeman Wins NL MVP
Content: Atlanta Braves first baseman Freddie  Freeman won the National League MVP award on Thursday. Freeman received 28 of the 30 first-place ballots. Dodgers outfielder Mookie  Betts finished second and Padres third baseman Manny  Machado came in third. The 31-year-old tested positive for COVID-19 three weeks before the delayed Opening Day in late July and had 104.5 degree fever. Freeman got off to a slow start, but he finished the year hitting .341 with 13 home runs and 53 RBI in all 60 games. He led the majors with 23 doubles and 51 runs scored. He became the sixth different player in Braves history to win the MVP. A lefty hitter that can hit with power to all fields, Freeman is an elite fantasy first baseman.

Title: Trevor Bauer Wins NL Cy Young Award Wednesday
Content: Cincinnati Reds starting pitcher Trevor Bauer won the National League Cy Young Award on Wednesday over Cubs starter Yu Darvish and Mets right-hander Jacob deGrom. Bauer led the NL in ERA (1.73), ERA+ (276), WHIP (0.79), opponents' average (.159) and shutouts (two). The 29-year-old was second to only deGrom in strikeouts (100) and strikeouts per nine innings (12.3). Bauer finished strong as well, landing a 1.29 ERA in five September starts to fend of deGrom, who had won the award the previous two seasons. He also rejected the Reds $18.9 million qualifying offer, officially making him a free agent this winter. Especially after his Cy Young season, Bauer will be the most coveted free-agent arm on the open market, and he'll be a surefire fantasy ace no matter where he winds up.

Title: Kevin Cash Named AL Manager Of The Year
Content: Tampa Bay Rays manager Kevin Cash was named the American League Manager of the Year on Tuesday. Cash led the Rays to their first AL East title since 2010 despite having 13 players on the injured list on Sept. 1. Twelve Rays had at least one save and the pitching staff's 3.56 ERA was the third-lowest in baseball. Tampa went 40-20 during the shortened 2020 season with a plus-60 run differential. They lost to the Dodgers in six games in the World Series. Former White Sox manager Rick Renteria came in second place with five first-place votes, followed by Blue Jays skipper Charlie Montoyo (two first-place votes), A's manager Bob Melvin (one first-place vote), Twins manager Rocco Baldelli and Astros skipper Dusty Baker.

Title: Kyle Lewis Awarded AL Rookie Of The Year
Content: Seattle Mariners outfielder Kyle  Lewis was named the American League Rookie of the Year on Monday. The 25-year-old center fielder received all 30 first-place votes in the balloting, becoming the 12th unanimous winner of the AL award, joining Carlton Fisk, Derek Jeter, Mike  Trout and Aaron  Judge. He hit .262 with 11 home runs and 28 RBI in 58 games and led all rookies with 37 runs, 90 total bases and a .364 on-base percentage. White Sox outfielder Luis  Robert finished second in the voting, followed by Astros right-hander Cristian  Javier.  Lewis finished the shortened season by hitting just .147 in September. He was the 11th overall pick of the M's in the 2016 draft.

Title: Francisco Lindor Could Be A Target For Blue Jays
Content: Rival executives are expecting the Toronto Blue Jays to be among the big-spending teams in the offseason, and Cleveland Indians shortstop Francisco Lindor could be one of their targets. Many expect Lindor to be traded before Opening Day, as he's in his final year of arbitration eligibility after earning a prorated portion of his $17.5 million salary in 2020. Blue Jays president and CEO Mark Shapiro and general manager Ross Atkins were in the Indians front office when the team drafted Lindor with the eighth overall pick in 2011. Bo Bichette is currently at the 6 in Toronto, but they could move him to third base to accommodate Lindor. The start shortstop is projected to earn around $21 million in salary arbitration for the 2021 season.

Title: Brodie Van Wagenen Leaving Mets
Content: New York Mets general manager Brodie Van Wagenen and much of the team's front office are leaving the team after hedge-fund manager Steve Cohen completed his $2.4 billion purchase of the franchise on Friday. Special assistant to the GM Omar Minaya, assistant GMs Allard Baird and Adam Guttridge and executive director of player development Jared Banner are also leaving. Cohen hired GM Sandy Alderson as team president in his first move after taking over the team. Former owners Fred and Jeff Wilpon hired Van Wagenen to replace Alderson after the 2018 season. The Mets went 26-34 under manager Luis Rojas in 2020 and missed the postseason.

Title: Ronald Acuna Jr., Freddie Freeman Win Silver Sluggers
Content: Atlanta Braves outfielders Ronald  Acuna  Jr. and Marcell Ozuna, first baseman Freddie  Freeman and catcher Travis  d'Arnaud all won Silver Slugger Awards on Thursday. The rest of the National League Silver Sluggers included San Francisco Giants second baseman Donovan  Solano, San Diego Padres shortstop Fernando  Tatis  Jr., Padres third baseman Manny  Machado, Washington Nationals outfielder Juan  Soto and Los Angeles Dodgers outfielder Mookie  Betts. Acuna, Freeman and Ozuna were awarded Silver Sluggers for the second time, while d'Arnaud was a first-time winner for Atlanta.

Title: Trevor Bauer Open To Return To Cincinnati
Content: Free-agent right-hander Trevor Bauer rejected the Cincinnati Reds $18.9 million qualifying offer for the 2021 season on Wednesday, but he's open to discussing a return to the Reds. The 29-year-old went 5-4 with a National League-leading 1.73 ERA in 11 starts in 2020 and is a leading finalist for the NL Cy Young Award. Bauer's salary during the 2020 season was $17.5 million. If Bauer leaves Cincinnati in free agency, the Reds will receive draft-pick compensation next year. He has gone 75-64 with a 3.90 ERA in nine MLB seasons after being taken third overall by the Diamondbacks in 2011. Bauer will be a fantasy ace in 2021, mainly for his strikeout upside.

Title: Alex Gordon Wins Eighth Gold Glove In Final Season
Content: Kansas City Royals outfielder Alex  Gordon, who announced his retirement at the end of the 2020 season, won his eighth and final Gold Glove award on Tuesday. The 36-year-old finished off his career by winning a Gold Glove in four straight seasons. The other American League winners included Seattle Mariners first baseman Evan  White, Cleveland Indians second baseman Cesar Hernandez, Mariners shortstop J.P.  Crawford, Texas Rangers third baseman Isiah  Kiner-Falefa, Chicago White Sox center fielder Luis  Robert, Rangers right fielder Joey  Gallo, Indians catcher Roberto  Perez and Los Angeles Angels starting pitcher Griffin  Canning.

Title: Charlie Morton Prefers To Play For Rays
Content: Free-agent starting pitcher Charlie Morton's agent, B.B. Abbott, said that his client "wants to play" next season, but only in the right personal and professional situation. The 36-year-old had his $15 million option for 2021 declined, making him a free agent, but he said he prefers to return to the Tampa Bay Rays and keep pitching near his Florida home. Morton plans to "keep an open mind" about offers from other teams. The veteran righty finished third in the American League Cy Young voting in 2019 but had a 4.74 ERA (3.45 FIP) in 38 regular season innings this year. Morton has been excellent in the playoffs in his career, but his decline in the shortened 2020 season will have fantasy managers wary that he can be a No. 1 fantasy starter if he returns in 2021.

Title: Mitch Moreland's Option Declined By Padres
Content: The San Diego Padres declined a 2021 team option on first baseman Mitch  Moreland and he will become a free agent. With the universal designated hitter in question, the Friars opted against a reasonable $3 million price tag for Moreland, who they acquired via trade in 2020. With the resurgence of incumbent first baseman Eric  Hosmer, Moreland's left-handed bat became redundant. The 35-year-old veteran slashed just .203/.247/.362 with two homers in 73 plate appearances in San Diego, while posting a .894 and swatting 10 dingers overall between the Padres and Boston Red Sox. A bonafide slugger, Moreland will surely get another shot somewhere but without bankable playing time, his fantasy viability will be shaky.

Title: Cubs Decline Jon Lester's Option
Content: The Chicago Cubs declined starting pitcher Jon  Lester's $25 million team option on Friday, making him a free agent. The 36-year-old southpaw was at the end of his six-year, $155 million deal with the Cubs, but he could still return on a lesser deal. Lester will receive a $10 million buyout. The three-time World Series champion is optimistic that he can get something worked out and return to Chicago. Lester struggled with some mechanical issues in 2020 but rebounded late in the year to finish 3-3 with a 5.16 ERA. The Cubs will also decline their option on infielder Daniel  Descalso, who will be owed a $1 million buyout.

Title: Tigers Finalizing Deal To Make A.J. Hinch Their Manager
Content: The Detroit Tigers have made progress in finalizing a deal to make former Houston Astros manager A.J. Hinch their next manager, according to sources. Hinch lost his job with Houston before the start of the 2020 season for his role in the team's sign-stealing scandal. Former Tigers manager Ron Gardenhire retired on Sept. 19 with just over a week left in the season. Detroit went 23-35 during the shortened 2020 season, finishing last in the American League Central for the third time in the last four years. Their top two pitching prospects, Casey Mize and Tarik Skubal, saw their first big league experience.

Title: Nats Decline Options On Adam Eaton, Anibal Sanchez, Others
Content: The Washington Nationals declined club options for the 2021 season on outfielder Adam  Eaton and right-hander Anibal  Sanchez, making them free agents. The Nats also declined their portion of mutual options on infielders Howie  Kendrick and Eric  Thames. Eaton's option was worth $10.5 million, but they'll instead pay him a $1.5 million buyout. Sanchez's option was for $12 million and he'll receive a $2 million buyout. Kendrick will get a $2.25 million buyout after his $6.5 million option wasn't picked up. Thames had a $4 million mutual option but will receive a $1 million buyout. Eaton hit just .226 with four home runs and 17 RBI after excelling in last year's World Series. Sanchez was 4-5 with a 6.62 ERA in 11 starts for Washington in 2020. The 37-year-old Kendrick hit .275 with two homers and 14 RBI this year. Thames batted only .203 with three home runs and 12 RBI in his only season in D.C.

Title: Corey Seager Named World Series MVP
Content: Los Angeles Dodgers shortstop Corey  Seager was named the World Series Most Valuable Player after earning the same honor in the National League Championship Series. Seager hit .400 with two home runs, five RBI and six walks in six games in the World Series against the Rays. He hit .310 with five home runs and 11 RBI in the seven-game win over the Braves in the NLCS, including three long balls in Games 5 and 6. The previous MVP of both the League Championship Series and the World Series in the same year was Giants lefty Madison  Bumgarner in 2014. Only eight players have ever accomplished that, and they've all been in the National League.

Title: Tony Gonsolin To Start Game 6 Of World Series
Content: Los Angeles Dodgers rookie right-hander Tony  Gonsolin will start Game 6 of the World Series against the Rays on Tuesday. He'll be opposed by left-hander Blake  Snell for Tampa Bay. Snell, who won the American League Cy Young in 2018, didn't allow a hit to the Dodgers through the first four innings of Game 2 but ended up with a no-decision in the eventual Rays win. Gonsolin was essentially the opener for the Dodgers in Game 2, and he has a rough 9.39 ERA in 7 2/3 postseason innings after a strong regular season for LA. Manager Dave Roberts said there was no thought to bringing right-hander Walker  Buehler back on short rest for Game 6. Gonsolin will be a risky DFS selection because he'll likely have a very short leash in this one.

Title: Mets Claim Robel Garcia Off Of Waivers From Reds
Content: The New York Mets claimed infielder Robel Garcia off of waivers from the Cincinnati Reds on Monday. Garcia last appeared in the majors in 2019 for the Chicago Cubs hitting .208 with five home runs and 11 RBI in just 80 plate appearances. The move by the Mets was strictly for depth purposes. Even assuming Garcia makes the major league team out of spring training in 2021, he won't hold much fantasy value.

Title: Matt Strahm To Have Knee Surgery
Content: San Diego Padres left-handed pitcher Matt  Strahm (knee) will undergo a patellar tendon repair in his right knee. He underwent a similar surgery on his left knee in 2017 when he was with the Royals. Strahm went 0-1 with a 2.61 ERA in 19 outings in his third season with the Friars this year. The 28-year-old southpaw made 46 appearances in 2019 and started 16 of those, sporting a 4.71 ERA and 1.25 WHIP while striking out 9.3 hitters per nine innings. In his five MLB seasons, Strahm has made 151 appearances, with only 24 coming in the form of a start. He can be ignored in the vast majority of fantasy leagues heading into the 2021 season.

Title: Charlie Morton Gets The Nod For Game 3 Of World Series
Content: Tampa Bay Rays starting pitcher Charlie  Morton, who is 5-0 in five playoff starts with the team, will get the ball for Game 3 of the World Series against the Dodgers on Friday. Morton's velocity was down during the regular season, but he's been great in the postseason. The right-hander threw 5 2/3 scoreless innings in just 66 pitches in Game 7 of the American League Championship Series against the Astros. The 36-year-old is 3-0 with a 0.57 ERA in three playoff starts this year, with opposing hitters sporting just a .474 OPS against him. Morton helped beat the Dodgers in Game 7 of the World Series with the Astros back in 2017. The playoff experience and success is there, but he's also facing a historically stacked Dodgers lineup, making him a risk/reward DFS choice.

Title: Dodgers Expected To Go With Bullpen In Game 2
Content: Los Angeles Dodgers manager Dave Roberts wasn't willing to divulge who would start Game 2 of the World Series against the Rays on Wednesday. "It's going to be a bullpen, whatever, kind of game, using various arms," Roberts said. "Who starts that game, I just don't know yet." They'll be opposed by 2018 American League Cy Young winner Blake Snell, who went 4-2 with a 3.24 ERA in 11 regular season starts. Snell has gone 2-2 with a 3.20 ERA in four playoff starts. Left-hander Julio Urias and right-handers Dustin May and Tony Gonsolin are all options to get the nod for the Dodgers. Urias is 4-0 in the playoffs, with his only start coming in Game 3 of the National League Championship Series. Urias could also be a potential starter for Game 4.

Title: Walker Buehler To Start Game 3 Of World Series
Content: Los Angeles Dodgers starting pitcher Walker  Buehler will start Game 3 of the World Series against the Rays on Friday. Buehler started Game 1 in the first three rounds of the playoffs, but he just pitched on Saturday in Game 6 of the National League Championship Series. Instead, lefty Clayton  Kershaw will be pitching on normal rest in Game 1 on Tuesday. Buehler will be going on five days of rest on Friday after he tossed six scoreless innings last Saturday against Atlanta. The right-handed Buehler would be set up to start a deciding Game 7, if necessary. Buehler is likely to be matched up against veteran right-hander Charlie  Morton in Game 3 on Friday. He'll be a fine DFS play in the Fall Classic's third game.
